chapter.title: Scope
chapter.para: This document defines how WebRTC and related protocols are to be used for ONVIF clients and devices to establish a peer-to-peer connection between a client and a device using a signaling server.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The WebRTC standard includes APIs for communicating with an ICE Server, but the signaling component is not part of it. Signaling is needed in order for two peers to share how they should connect.
Signaling can be implemented in many different ways, and the WebRTC standard doesn't prefer any specific solution.

This specification contains documentation and examples of the signaling protocol used in ONVIF to set up a WebRTC peer-to-peer connection. The setup involves three participants: client, device and signaling server.

In this figure,
The client represents a real user who initiates the WebRTC session.
The device is the resource delivering the media, for example a camera.
The signaling server is the mediator that both client and device connect to in order to establish a peer-to-peer connection between them.
The Signaling Protocol described in this specification details the data exchange between client and device via the signaling server. The formal API is defined in a separate AsyncAPI schema file.
Once a peer-to-peer connection has been established, how WebRTC is used is described in the WebRTC usage chapter.

chapter.title: Signaling Protocol
chapter.para: The Signaling Protocol defines the messages between a client and a device in a WebRTC system with the intension of esatblishing a peer-to-peer connection between the client and a device. The messages are always sent via the signaling server called server from now on. Once a peer-to-peer connection has been established the connection with the server can be dropped without affecting the peer-to-peer connection. It's however recommended to keep the server connection open to be able receive error messages from the server.

section.title: WebSocket Connection Management
section.para: Both a client and a device need to connect to the server by setting up a WebSocket connection according to [RFC 6455].
A device shall connect to a signaling server as soon as the configuration contains a valid URI.
In case a connection is dropped the device shall reconnect automatically. Each client should use an individual ascending interval strategy to avoid that all clients reconnect at the same time.
Both device and client shall immediately send a register command as specified in section when they receive the HTTP 101 switching protocol..

section.title: Communication Protocol
section.para: The communication protocols shall use JSON-RPC version 2 over a WebSocket connection . Parameters and responses shall be passed by name. The table below provides the encodings to be used.

entry.para: SDP according to RFC 8866 with \r\n escaping
JSON encoding according to W3C WebRTC RTCIceCandidateInit
Connection parameters for a STUN or TURN server as defined by W3C WebRTC
STUN or TURN server url encoded according to RFC 7064 or RFC 7065

section.para: The following sections specify the parameters of the indivdual commands.

section.title: register
section.para: A signaling server shall expect this command to be sent once before any other command is sent over the WebSocket connection. The signaling server shall verify the validity of the access token. Token details are outside of the scope of this specification.

listitem.para: Access token that authorizes the device or client..
The unnique ID of the device or client.
The human readable name of the device or client.
The ID assigned by the signaling server to the endpoint.
The JWT token cannot be verified, does not include the required claims or has expired.

section.title: connect
section.para: An ONVIF compliant signaling server and device shall support this command to establish a streaming session between two peers.

listitem.para: The ID of the peer to connect to.
Access token that authorizes the device or client..
Optional token of the media streaming profile to connect to.
List of STUN and TURN servers to be used.
The ID assigned by the signaling server to the session.
List of STUN and TURN servers to be used.
The JWT token cannot be verified, does not include the required claims or has expired.
The target device is currently unavailable.

section.para: An ONVIF compliant signaling server shall provide a list of STUN and TURN servers in both request and response such that both device and client use the same set of ICE servers. A compliant client and device shall support password based authentication of TURN server.
An ONVIF compliant device shall issue an invite method immediately after responding to this method.

section.title: invite
section.para: An ONVIF compliant signaling server shall support this command to establish a streaming session between two peers. It shall forward this command to the client and correspondingly route the response back to the device.
The dynamics and the format of the SDP records are defined in RFC 8829.

listitem.para: The ID assigned by the signaling server to the session.
The SDP offer provided by the device.
The SDP answer provided by the client.
Invalid session ID or SDP payload.
The peer is no more available.

section.title: trickle
section.para: An ONVIF compliant signaling server, device and client shall support this command to signal new ICE candidates for the trickleICE procedure as defined in RFC 8840.
A signaling server shall relay this command unaltered to the peer.

listitem.para: The ID assigned by the signaling server to the session.
The ICE Candidate SDP update for the peer.

section.para: Both client and device produce ICE candidates and send them to each other, via the server, in any order.
NOTE: Note that ICE candidates can arrive before the SDP offer and the implementing client needs to handle this.

If everything works as it should, a peer-to-peer WebRTC session can be set up between client and device. After the session has been established the client can terminate the WebSocket session to the signaling server and the peer-to-peer connection will not be affected. However, it's recommended to keep the WebSocket session to the server open to be able to receive event messages from the signaling server.

chapter.title: WebRTC Usage
chapter.para: This chapter describes ONVIF specific usage of WebRTC regarding how to send data between the client and device on the peer-to-peer connection.

Devices MAY define profiles for different streaming scenarios that can be choosen by the client based on the available bandwidth or other limiting factors. For example, a specific profile for mobile clients, another one for high quality streaming, etc.

section.title: Video
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the h.264 codec.
In line with WebRTC standard, ONVIF also recommends to always use congestion control to ensure that WebRTC cannot be used to flood the network.

section.title: Audio
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the Opus or PCMU codec.
For two-way audio it's recommended to use echo cancellation to avoid feedback loops.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: A device could send event and analytics metadata on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

section.title: Commands
section.para: A client could send PTZ and other commands on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in the this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

chapter.title: Directory Protocol
chapter.para: The Directory Protocol is used to query organizations, devices and profiles in a directory. This is out-of-scope for this release of the specification. The client has to find out in a proprietary way what devices that it can connect to and what profiles that are available for those devices.

chapter.title: Authentication Protocol
chapter.para: This section describes how users and devices autheticates and get access to services.

section.title: User login and access
section.para: A user logs in and gets an access token using OAuth2 and OpenID Connect. This is described in the [ONVIF Security Service Specification].

section.title: Device access
section.para: In order for a device to connect to a signaling server an Authorization Server Configuration must have been set up during device onboarding. See the [ONVIF Security Service] regarding Authorization Server Configurations. This configuration tells the device how to get an access token that can be used to connect to the signaling server. Typically a configuration is created that allows the device to use OAuth2 Client Credentials Grant flow using private_key_jwt as client authentication method as described in [OpenID Connect Core]. In case private_key_jwt is used, the JWT contains these claims:

entry.para: client_id, an id that uniqely identifies the device, e.g. orgId/deviceId
client_id, an id that uniqely identifies the device, e.g. orgId/deviceId

section.para: NOTE: This is one way for a device to authenticate. Other setups are possible depending on the specific Authorization Server and Signaling Server configurations.

section.title: What needs to be provisioned during onboarding
section.para: In order for a device to be able to function in a WebRTC system the following things needs to be provisioned during device onboarding:

listitem.para: ClientSecret: Key ID of the private signing key
Scope: optional depending on Authorization Server
Signaling Server URI: The URI where the device should connect to
Any CA certs that are needed to connect to the Authorization Server and Signaling server
orgId: The id of the organization that the device belongs to
deviceId: The device's unique id within the organization
